1. REF: the social card of residents of Ivanovo region is to be recognised as an electronic payment instrument .

    HYP: the social map of the Ivanovo region is recognized as an electronic means of payment .


  2. REF: these changes make allowances for the preservation of discounted travel on public transportation .

    HYP: the changes include preserving the benefits of public passenger transport .


  3. REF: starting on September 24 , the organisation of discounted travel for citizens of Ivanovo region using the social card will change .

    HYP: on September 24 , is changing the order of concessionary travel organization citizens using the social map of the Ivanovo region .


  4. REF: the press service for the Government of Russia for Ivanovo region reports that the changes make allowances for the preservation of discounted travel on public transportation and introduce a system of mutual settlements on the social card in accordance with the requirements of Federal Law No . 161 `` On the National Payment System '' .

    HYP: according to the press service of the Russian government on the Ivanovo region , the changes include preserving benefits for travel in public passenger transport and bring social card payments scheme in accordance with the requirements of the Federal Law No . 161 of the federal law `` on the national payment system '' .


  5. REF: moreover , the social card of residents of Ivanovo region is to be recognised as an electronic payment instrument .

    HYP: the social map of the Ivanovo region is recognized as an electronic means of payment .


  6. REF: accordingly , the conditions of its use will change .

    HYP: accordingly , changing the conditions of its application .


  7. REF: for example , the loading limit is no longer set according to trips as before , but rather according to an amount of money ; and the winter and summer periods will be maintained : in the winter , it will be no more than 400 roubles , and , in the summer , no more than 800 roubles for a given month .

    HYP: so , the limit of replenishment is now not travel as before , and the amount of cash , with saving winter and summer periods - no more than 400 rubles in winter , in summer - no more than 800 roubles for the current month .


  8. REF: now , when they are issued a transit receipt , social card holders will need to keep track of the balance of funds on the card and not the number of remaining trips .

    HYP: now owners of social cards issued in transport receipts will need to keep track of the number of remaining trips , and the rest of the money .


  9. REF: the cost of discounted travel for citizens will amount to 1/2 the fare of the applicable carrier .

    HYP: the cost of concessionary travel for citizens is 1/2 of the current tariff from the carrier .


  10. REF: the other half of the fare will be paid for from the regional budget .

    HYP: the remaining half of the cost of travel reimburses the regional budget .


  11. REF: the schedule for topping up the social card with funds will stay the same : during the period between the 24th of the previous month through to the 23rd of the current month .

    HYP: the schedule of replenishment social cash card remains the same - the number of the previous month from 24 to 23 the number of the current month .


  12. REF: the new procedure for travelling with a social card will have a number of advantages .

    HYP: the new order of social travel card will have a number of advantages .


  13. REF: for example , it becomes possible to conduct detailed accounting of the expenditure of funds on the social card down to the last kopeck .

    HYP: so , there is the opportunity to keep a detailed record of spending money on social card with an accuracy of kopeks .


  14. REF: moreover , it becomes possible to refund loaded but unspent funds .

    HYP: in addition , there is a possibility of returning credited , but unspent money .


  15. REF: it 's also worth noting that the system of mutual settlements with carriers will become transparent , since a citizen now pays for half of the fare , and the carrier will be reimbursed in the exact same amount from the budget .

    HYP: add also that the settlement scheme with carriers becomes transparent , as now half of the fare paid by the citizen , and the same amount to offset the budget carrier .


  16. REF: no commission fee will be charged for loading funds onto the card .

    HYP: no commission when making the cash card will not be charged .


  17. REF: in turn , Vasily Silkin , Deputy Head of the Department of Public Roads and Transportation for Ivanovo region , reported that more than 33 million trips had been made using the social card in 2014 , and , in 2015 , almost 25 million trips .

    HYP: in turn , Vasily silkin , zamestetel head of the Department of road and transport of the Ivanovo region , reported that in 2014 in the region was committed more than 33 million trips using social card , 2015-m - almost 25 million trips .

    HYP: in the regional budget for granting preferential travel for citizens using social card provided more than 470 million rubles .


  19. REF: as of September 1 , the total spent for this purpose amounted to more than 312 million roubles .

    HYP: as of September 1 , the amount of compensation for these purposes was more than 312 million rubles .

    HYP: you can download the BBC News app for iOS or Android devices and send us pictures or articles using the buttons in the application .

    HYP: submit your stories and comments to haveyoursay @ bbc.co.uk

    HYP: send your images , video or audio to us at yourpics @ bbc.co.uk

    HYP: you can also upload your video or photos on the site .

    HYP: we will publish your name as you specify , or we will not publish at your request .

    HYP: the migration crisis in Europe : Hungary announces emergency , closing the border , detain migrants

  326. REF: chaos ensued at the border , as hundreds of migrants piled up in a no man 's land , and Serbian officials reacted with outrage .

    HYP: the unrest occurred at the border - has accumulated hundreds of migrants on the border area , which dramatically reacted negatively on the Serbian authorities .


  327. REF: stuck for an unknown amount of time on a strip of road between the two countries ' checkpoints , those fleeing violence in their homelands pitched tents and settled in .

    HYP: however , growing discontent .

  330. REF: some refused food and water in protest .

    HYP: some in the protest refused food and water .

  332. REF: ( Serbia ) wants to be part of the solution , not collateral damage .

    HYP: Serbia wants to be part of the solution to the problem rather than collateral damage .

    HYP: it is necessary in the coming days to hold negotiations with Brussels and other countries , `` said Ivica Dacic in Prague .

    HYP: the unrest at the Serbian border started the next day after a block of 28 countries failed to develop a common immigration policy at a joint meeting in Brussels .


  335.     HYP: the ministers agreed to take total responsibility for 40,000 people seeking refuge in crowded Italy and Greece , and expressed the hope that in the future ( in the next month or by the end of the year ) will be reached , according to which the Member States of the European Union will take another 120 000 refugees , including refugees from Hungary .


  336. REF: German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Austria called Tuesday for a special European Union summit next week to discuss the continent 's immigration crisis .

    HYP: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and Austria on Tuesday demanded to assemble an emergency EU summit next week to discuss the immigration crisis that has gripped the continent .


  337. REF: Hungary , however , was not pinning its hopes on any action soon from Brussels or its neighbors .

    HYP: Hungary , however , hopes for quick action on the part of Brussels or neighbors .


  338. REF: Tuesday 's state of emergency in two southern regions gave authorities greater powers to deal with the crisis , allowing them to shut down roads and speed up asylum court cases .

    HYP: on Tuesday declared a state of emergency in two southern regions gave authorities more powers to act against the crisis that allowed them to cut off roads and speed up court cases for asylum .


  339. REF: meanwhile , Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto said his country is also planning to build a razor-wire fence along part of its border with Romania to stop the flow of migrants through the country , now that it has finished a fence on the Serbian border .

    HYP: meanwhile , the Minister of Foreign Affairs Vengy Peter Sillarto said his country plans to erect a fence with barbed wire on the border with Romania to halt the flow of migrants through the country , now that she has finished a fence on the Serbian border .


  340. REF: CBS News correspondent Charlie D'Agata reported that even prison inmates were enlisted in the race to finish the razor wire fence between Hungary and Serbia .

    HYP: CBS News correspondent Charlie Dagat reported that even prisoners were connected to the urgent work on the completion of the barbed wire fence between Hungary and Serbia .


  341. REF: in the last few months , Hungary has become a major bottleneck and entry point into the European Union for migrants , many of them war refugees from Syria and elsewhere in the Middle East .

    HYP: over the past few months , Hungary has become the main `` bottleneck '' and the EU 's border crossing point for migrants , many of whom are refugees - victims of the war in Syria and the countries of the Middle East .


  342. REF: Prime Minister Viktor Orban , however , has insisted that most arriving are economic migrants seeking a better life , not war refugees entitled to protection - a view sharply at odds with other EU nations , including Germany .

    HYP: nevertheless , the country 's Prime Minister Viktor Orban insists that the majority of people arriving in the country are economic migrants seeking a more prosperous life , not refugees - victims of military actions that have the right to protection , and this view is sharply at odds with the views of the other EU countries , including Germany .


  343. REF: the new laws that took effect at midnight in Hungary now make it a crime to cross or damage a 4-meter ( 13-foot ) razor-wire fence the government has built along the southern border with Serbia and also includes longer prison terms for convicted human traffickers .

    HYP: the new law , which took effect at midnight in Hungary , consider now a crime crossing or damage 4-metrový ( 13-foot ) fence with barbed wire , built by the government along the southern border with Serbia , and also include longer prison sentences for defendants in trafficking .


  344. REF: `` Due to the situation caused by mass migration , the Hungarian government declares a state of crisis , '' government spokesman Zoltan Kovacs told reporters in the southern city of Szeged .

    HYP: `` Because of the situation caused by mass migration , the Hungarian government declared a state of emergency , '' government spokesman Zoltan Kovacs told reporters in the southern city of Szeged .


  345. REF: we are very clear on this : illegal border crossing is a crime .

    HYP: we clearly understand : crossing the border illegally is a crime .

    HYP: György Bakondi , Orban 's adviser on national security , reported apprehending authorised bodies of 45 people who tried to cross the border , the border , and another 15 people inside the country .


  348. REF: they got across by damaging the fence , are now in police custody and are being charged with committing offenses under the new laws .

    HYP: they crossed the border , breaking the fence , are currently in police custody and accused of committing administrative violations under the new laws .


  349. REF: authorities are quickly repairing the fence .

    HYP: the authorities quickly re-established the fence .

    HYP: the Hungarian authorities on Tuesday morning also closed two of seven passes on the border with Serbia , driving to block one of the railway passes , festooned with barbed wire .

  367. REF: a quarter would support her with some reservations and another 15 percent would only back her because she is the nominee .

    HYP: a quarter would have supported her with some reservations , and another 15 percent would support her just because she is a candidate .


  368. REF: six percent would not support her .

    HYP: six per cent would not have supported it .

    HYP: among those who are currently not supporting Clinton , more controversial views - only about a quarter of her enthusiastically supported .

    HYP: among supporters of Clinton , more than half said they would choose Biden 's second , it is more than Sanders .

  448. REF: more specifically , the market over the past 35 years or so is most often up sharply - about 14 percent - heading into the rate hike , fairly flat in the 250 days after ( average gain of 2.6 percent ) then back to normal once 500 days have passed , with average return in the past six cycles of 14.4 percent , according to a recent analysis Bob Doll , chief equity strategist at Nuveen Asset Management , posted on Barron 's .

    HYP: if specifically , the market roughly over the last 35 years , often dramatically changes - some 14 percent - toward raising rates , remains smooth enough for 250 days after that ( the average growth of 2.6 per cent ) , then , after 500 days , returned to normal with an average yield of 14.4 percent in the last six cycles , according to a recent analysis by Bob Doll , chief equity trading strategy specialist at Nuveen Asset Management , published in Barron 's .

    HYP: Deutsche said the result for securities tends not to immediately become more pronounced at higher rates , and income from stocks begin to shrink .

    HYP: scientific article published by the group , `` gracefully agrees '' with the fact that there is a lack of `` compelling evidence of the harmful effects of most products on most criteria , '' wrote McKee and Keipwell .

    HYP: however , none of these connections and limitations were not affected in the PHE report .

    HYP: he explained : `` Electronic cigarettes are significantly less harmful than smoking . ''

    HYP: one of the two smoked all his life died from his addiction .

    HYP: all the evidence implies that the health threats from electronic cigarettes are relatively small , but we must continue to explore distant consequences .

    HYP: about 80,000 people per year die from diseases associated with smoking and smoking costs the NHS 2 billion pounds per year .

  879. REF: 'Sonogenetics ' allows brain cells to be controlled by sound waves

    HYP: `` Sonogenetics '' allows you to control the brain cells using sound waves


  880. REF: the video shows how the nematodes change direction the moment they are blasted with sonic pulses .

    HYP: the video shows how the nematodes change the direction of the movement at the moment when they are exposed to sound impulses .


  881. REF: scientists have bred worms with genetically modified nervous systems that can be controlled by bursts of sound waves .

    HYP: scientists put the worms with genetically modified nervous system that can be controlled by using ispuls sound waves .


  882. REF: the tiny nematodes change direction the moment they are blasted with sonic pulses that are too high-pitched for humans to hear .

    HYP: tiny nematodes change the direction of the movement when they affect sound impulses , too high to the human ear can hear .


  883. REF: the pulses work by switching on motor neuron cells that are genetically modified to carry membrane channels that respond to ultrasonic waves .

    HYP: impulses influenced by activating neurons , genetically modified to use membrane channels that respond to ultrasonic waves .


  884. REF: related : researchers read and write brain activity with light

    HYP: still on the topic : researchers manage brain activity with the help of light


  885. REF: researchers said the worms demonstrate the power of a new procedure , dubbed sonogenetics , in which ultrasound can be used to activate a range of brain , heart and muscle cells from outside the body .

    HYP: scientists said that the worms are demonstrating the possibilities of a new technique called `` sonogenetics '' , the essence of which is to use ultrasound to initiate certain cells of the brain , heart and muscles , the ultrasound source is located outside of the body .


  886. REF: Sreekanth Chalasani , a researcher at the Salk Institute in La Jolla , California , told the Guardian that the procedure could one day replace deep-brain stimulation , an invasive procedure that delivers electrical pulses into people 's brains to treat symptoms of Parkinson 's disease .

    HYP: historical Analysis Chalasaṃuti , a researcher at the Salk Institute , La Jolla , California , told the Guardian that this technique could one day replace deep brain stimulation - an invasive procedure , in which a person is sent electrical impulses in the brain and that is used in the treatment of Parkinson 's disease .


  887. REF: nematode worms do not usually react to ultrasound , but Chalasani found that they did when they were surrounded by a fluid containing microscopic bubbles .

    HYP: worms nematodes usually do not react to ultrasound , but Chalasanya discovered that they started to react when they were placed in a fluid containing microscopic bubbles .


  888. REF: the bubbles , he found , amplify the ultrasonic waves which then pass inside the worms .

    HYP: he discovered that the bubbles reinforce ultrasonic waves that penetrate into the body of the worms .


  889. REF: the amplified ultrasound waves act on structures called TRP-4 ion channels , found in the membranes of some of the worms '' cells .

    HYP: reinforced ultrasonic waves affect structures called `` ion channels TRP-4 '' found in the membranes of cells of worms .


  890. REF: the sound waves make these ion channels open up and activate the cells they are attached to , according to a report in Nature Communications .

    HYP: ultrasonic waves make these ion channels open and excite the cells that are associated with them , according to a report in Nature Communications .


  891. REF: to make ultrasound-controlled nematodes , Chalasani genetically modified the worms so that some of their motor neurons carried TRP-4 ion channels .

    HYP: to create the nematodes that can be controlled through ultrasound , Chalasanya made genetic modifications of worms , so their motor neurons used ion channels TRP-4 .


  892. REF: when he applied ultrasound to the modified creatures , the sound waves were amplified by the microbubbles and transmitted into the worms , where they switched on the modified motor neurons .

    HYP: during the use of ultrasound to influence the modified organisms sound waves reinforced microscopic bubbles and put into organisms worms , activating the modified motor neurons .


  893. REF: the procedure has some similarities with optogenetics , a groundbreaking tool that allows scientists to switch neurons on and off with pulses of light .

    HYP: this technique is similar to that used in the `` optogenetics '' - a new direction that allows scientists to activate neurons using light pulses .


  894. REF: but Chalasani said that sonogenetics could have some advantages over that technique .

    HYP: Chalasaṃa claims compared to this methodology sonogenetics may have some advantages .


  895. REF: unlike light , which has to be sent down an optic fibre to the desired location inside the brain , low frequency ultrasound waves can pass through tissue unhindered , and so can be sent into the brain from on top of the skull .

    HYP: unlike the light that is delivered to the target area of the brain by fiber optics , low-frequency ultrasound waves freely pass through the body 's tissue , so to deliver them does not need to pass inside cranial boxes .


  896. REF: `` We believe that , using gene therapy and a therapeutic virus , it may be possible to make target human neurons temporarily susceptible to the ultrasound signal in a clinical setting for certain neurological treatments , '' said Chalasani .

    HYP: `` We believe that for the treatment of certain neurological diseases in clinical conditions , the use of gene therapy and therapeutic viruses will be able to make human neurons sensitive to ultrasound signals , '' said Chalasaṃa .


  897. REF: other applications could focus on muscle cells and insulin-producing cells , he added .

    HYP: he added that , in addition to this , the technique can be applied to muscular and insulin-producing cells .

    HYP: Lee was not romantic , if your future spouse settled in the same dormitory as you ?

    HYP: on the contrary , there would not be this extremely , before biting elbows , awkwardly , if you take a neighbor for his future wife , was fond of them , had broken relationships and would see him every day , and watch how he might drag on his side of all of your friends in common ?

    HYP: of course , the heart is not ordered - but if a neighbor is definitely not your future spouse , try to cool slightly own fervor .

    HYP: a good draw is fun , but turns into its opposite in seconds .

    HYP: taught valuable and interesting lesson for security by hiding something - but never gave some room toothpaste and shampoo .

    HYP: according to him , the proposed practice successfully operates abroad : in prison ( where the defendants before the court decision ) provides separate cameras for transgenders and in correctional facilities - special blocks .


  1037. REF: currently , this is the only way of dealing with these types of criminals .

    HYP: today it is the only way out when dealing with such criminals .

  1041. REF: separate pre-trial detention facilities are n't necessary , just separate cells , and blocs in prisons .

    HYP: do n't exactly need a separate prison - only cameras , blocks in prisons .

    HYP: yes , a separate colony is possible if there will be many transgender people .

  1044. REF: citizens are held in pre-trial detention facilities according to the place where the crime was committed , and , as such , the arrival of transvestites or transgender people from different territorial subjects during the investigation and court proceedings is unrealistic ; however , introducing this practice in a separate colony , for those who have already been convicted is definitely possible , Grib believes .

    HYP: citizens kept in pre-trial detention at the place of the crime , therefore receiving transvestites or transgenders from other subjects during the investigation and trial are unrealistic , but to introduce such a practice already convicted in a separate colony - yes , `` says mushroom .


  1045.     HYP: recall on the eve of the law enforcement agencies failed to decide on remand - male or female - to determine who was detained for possession of drugs 24-year-old transsexual Dmitry Kozhukov ( known as Alina Davis ) , a man with a girlish appearance had not been arrested .

    HYP: he was released home under subscription .

  1048.     HYP: prisons should be safe , so separate blocks could be done in the name of this and for homosexuals , especially because their prisons more than transgender people .

    HYP: while Alexeev doubts that Russia will prove a lot of citizens willing to betray themselves for transsexuals to get into different from the usual colony .


  1053. REF: of course , a medical examination could be introduced before placing people into a penal colony for transgender people ; however , things are not always so straightforward .

    HYP: of course , you can enter a medical examination before placing people in the colonies for transgenders , but everything is not always clear .

  1055. REF: a person can feel like they are anyone at all .

    HYP: a person can feel themselves by anyone .


  1056. REF: however , as of yet , there are no separate facilities for transgender people to serve out their sentences , and I doubt that prison staff will think seriously about the safety of such people or fathom the complexities of their orientation or gender identification .

    HYP: but while some places to serve a sentence for transgenders no , I doubt that prison officials will think seriously about the safety of such people and understand their orientation or gender identity .


  1057. REF: at the same time , international expert on issues of reproductive health in the Russian Federation , Boris Lordkipanidze , noted that the introduction of a new system for assigning transsexual criminals to a penal colony could significantly delay the start of the convicts serving their sentences .

    HYP: at the same time , an international expert on reproductive health in the territory of the Russian Federation Boris Lordkipanidze noted that the introduction of a new system of distributing transgender criminals in the colony could greatly delay the start of the sentence convicts .


  1058. REF: a committee is created : this is a question of sexology , with psychiatrists conducting long-term examinations - this is not just one test - on the basis of which a highly precise diagnosis is made .

    HYP: the commission is created is a matter of sexology , psychiatrists conduct lengthy observations , this is not a test , which is based on a precise conclusion .


  1059. REF: modern practices in psychiatry make this possible .

    HYP: today 's capabilities of psychiatry is allowed .


  1060. REF: this is why , before a sex change , potential patients undergo such expert evaluation ; they will definitively show whether or not a sex change requiring surgery is a necessary measure , says Lordkipanidze .

    HYP: therefore , before potential patients undergo sex change always such expertise - they accurately indicate whether a change of sex with surgical intervention necessary measure , `` says Lordkipanidze .


  1061. REF: however , it is difficult for me to imagine how to introduce this system in relation to convicted individuals ; after all , on average , it takes an entire month to conduct such an examination .

    HYP: however , it is hard to imagine how this system implemented in relation to the condemned , because such examination takes a month on average .


  1062.   1063.     HYP: it is difficult to calculate , no official statistics , but given that homosexuals in Russia is around 5 % , it can be said that transgenders even less , and those who have such a rejection and also commits a crime , not an insignificant amount , `` said Lordkipanidze .

    HYP: what do you estimate , the situation today ?


  1151. REF: after the panicked mood at the end of 2014 and the beginning of 2015 , the volume of lending to SMEs declined significantly .

    HYP: after the panic of the end of 2014 - the beginning of 2015 SME lending volumes have decreased significantly .


  1152. REF: the reason is obvious : a sharp rise in interest rates .

    HYP: the reason is clear : a sharp increase in interest rates .


  1153. REF: financing at 25-30 % per annum was n't beneficial to anyone .

    HYP: lending by 25-30 % p.a . was not beneficial to anyone .


  1154. REF: if previously , a bank could place all of its potential future problems , from arrears to defaults , at a higher rate , then now it is no longer possible to do this : the rates are already sky-high .

    HYP: previously , the bank could lay in the increased rate of all its possible problems in the future , from delays to delinquencies , now it is impossible to make : rates and so sky-high .


  1155. REF: for the business community , the current level of interest rates for loans to SMEs is n't comfortable .

    HYP: the current level of business rates on loans to SMEs is uncomfortable .


  1156. REF: for a significant proportion of investment projects , the current level is unacceptable in terms of their rate of return .

    HYP: for a large part of the current level of investment projects is unacceptable from the point of view of their payback .


  1157. REF: an interest rate level of between 10-13 % would enable businesses to invest in a wide range of projects and make an attractive profit from them .

    HYP: the level of rates at 10-13 % would allow businesses to invest in a wide range of projects and build them attractive yield .


  1158. REF: in your opinion , to what extent is the demand for credit by business owners being met ?

    HYP: how do you estimate the demand met entrepreneurs for loans ?


  1159. REF: the situation improved slightly after the Central Bank lowered the interest rate .

    HYP: after lowering the central bank interest rates , the situation is slightly improved .


  1160. REF: credit resources became more readily available .

    HYP: credit resources have become more accessible .


  1161. REF: however , according to our observations , clients have started to apply for loans much more infrequently .

    HYP: however , according to our observations , customers began to seek loans far less frequently .


  1162. REF: first of all , businesses ca n't discern the prospects for their development or future earnings .

    HYP: first of all , business does not understand the prospects of its development and future revenues .


  1163. REF: today , businesses have one option : they need to learn how to operate by focusing on the current economic situation in the country and the region .

    HYP: today business is one way out : you need to learn to work , focusing on the current economic situation in the country and the region .


  1164. REF: it 's necessary to more closely monitor current performance and control cash flow .

    HYP: you need to more closely monitor the current results , to monitor the movement of cash .


  1165. REF: at the same time , when financial resources are available , it makes sense to use new technologies that allow for the modernisation of equipment and the reduction of production and energy costs .

    HYP: at the same time , the availability of financial resources should use new technology to modernize equipment , to reduce production costs and energy .


  1166. REF: all this , ultimately , enables companies to make their production more competitive and maintain their business even in an unstable economic situation .

    HYP: all this will ultimately allow companies to make products more competitive and maintain business even in an unstable economic situation .


  1167. REF: which main trends in the SME lending market will become more pronounced and will influence its development up until the end of 2015 ?

    HYP: what are the major trends of the SME lending market will be strengthened and will influence its development until the end of 2015 ?


  1168. REF: will the interest rate change ?

    HYP: will change the interest rate ?


  1169. REF: the forecast regarding a reduction of the average rate will depend a lot on the policies of the Central Bank ; currently , the regulator is demonstrating consistency when it comes to lowering the key rate .

    HYP: the average reduction forecast rates will largely depend on central bank policy , and now the regulator demonstrates a key sequence in the issue of lowering interest rates .


  1170. REF: however , there 's no point in waiting for a drastic decline in the cost of credit for SMEs .

    HYP: however , the radical decline in the price of loans for SMEs should not wait .


  1171. REF: in the current situation , the problem , first and foremost , is inflation , which necessitates a higher interest rate to obtain real earnings .

    HYP: in the current situation , the problem is primarily inflation , which makes the necessary increased interest rates to get real income .


  1172. REF: moreover , the cost of money in Russia will remain high even with a lowering of rates by the Central Bank .

    HYP: in addition , the value of money in Russia will remain high even with lower rates of central bank


  1173. REF: if we 're talking about the level of arrears , then traditionally , small and medium size businesses , limited by their ability to replenish funds , as well as by possibilities for adjusting economic behaviour , will , of course , present a big risk to lenders .

    HYP: speaking about the level of delay , traditionally small and medium-sized companies , limited in both opportunities to replenish cash and options for correction of economic behavior will certainly pose a greater risk for creditors .

  1877. REF: for mildly obese diabetics , weight loss surgery may be helpful

    HYP: diabetics with small obesity can help obesity surgery


  1878. REF: the benefits of weight loss surgery for mildly obese people with type 2 diabetes can last at least five years , according to a new study .

    HYP: a favorable effect after obesity surgery in people with obesity , type 2 diabetes , may last at least five years , according to a new study .


  1879. REF: it 's still to early to say whether mildly obese people with diabetes live longer after weight loss surgery than those who receive non-surgical treatments , however .

    HYP: however , it is still too early to say that diabetics with a small live longer after obesity surgery for obesity than those who receive non-surgical treatment .


  1880. REF: `` The mortality data take a long time to show up , '' said Dr. Robin Blackstone , a weight loss surgery expert who wrote an editorial on the new study in JAMA Surgery .

    HYP: `` The mortality statistics is not immediately , '' said Dr. Robin Blackstone , an expert on obesity surgery , wrote an editor 's column about a new study in JAMA Surgery .


  1881. REF: weight loss operations , or bariatric surgery , use various methods to shrink the size of the stomach .

    HYP: obesity surgery , or bariatric surgery , uses different methods to reduce the size of the stomach .


  1882. REF: they reduce hunger and limit the body 's ability to absorb food .

    HYP: they reduce the sense of hunger and restrict the ability of organis absorb food .


  1883. REF: over the years , bariatric surgeries have proved effective for treating type 2 diabetes , but most studies were done in people who are morbidly obese , with a body mass index ( BMI ) of 35 or above .

    HYP: for several years , bariatric surgery has proven to be effective for the treatment of type 2 diabetes , but the basic research was carried out among people with morbid obesity , having a body mass index ( BMI ) of 35 or higher .


  1884. REF: BMI , a measure of weight in relation to height , is considered normal between 18.5 and 24.9 .

    HYP: BMI , a measure of weight relative to height , is considered normal at value from 18.5 to 24.9 .


  1885. REF: a BMI of 25 or higher indicates that someone is overweight , and people with a BMI over 30 are considered obese .

    HYP: a BMI of 25 or above indicates that a person is overweight , and people with a BMI above 30 are considered obese .


  1886. REF: you can calculate your BMI here : 1.usa.gov/1D0ZqDv .

    HYP: you can calculate your BMI here : 1.usa.gov/1d0zqdv .


  1887. REF: for the new study , researchers from Taiwan 's Min-Sheng General Hospital used data collected since 2007 in a trial comparing two kinds of bariatric surgery - gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy - to medical treatments for type 2 diabetes in people who were mildly obese .

    HYP: for the new study , researchers from the Taiwan hospital min Sheng general used data collected since 2007 , to compare two types of bariatric surgery - gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy , with the medical treatment of type 2 diabetes in people with obesity .


  1888. REF: the average BMI among those who had surgery fell from 31 to 24.5 by the end of their fifth year in the study .

    HYP: the average BMI of those who have undergone surgery , fell from 31 to 24.5 by the end of the fifth year of their participation in the study .


  1889. REF: meanwhile , the BMI among those receiving non-surgical diabetes treatments stayed about the same at 29 .

    HYP: at the same time , the BMI of those who received non-surgical treatment for diabetes , remains roughly at the level of 29 .


  1890. REF: among those who had surgery , diabetes resolved completely in 36 percent and partially in 28 percent .

    HYP: among those who had surgery , completely cured of diabetes by 36 % , and partially - 28 % .


  1891. REF: in the medically-treated group , by comparison , diabetes resolved completely in only 1 percent and partially in only about 2 percent .

    HYP: in the group that received medical treatment , for comparison , a complete cure for diabetes was observed only 1 % , and partial - only about 2 % .


  1892. REF: in addition , control of blood pressure , triglycerides , and `` bad '' LDL cholesterol `` was generally better in the surgical group , '' the authors found .

    HYP: in addition , indicators of blood pressure , high triglycerides and `` bad '' LDL cholesterol `` as a whole were better in the surgical group , '' the authors said .


  1893. REF: the researchers also monitored patients ' blood levels of hemoglobin A1c , which reflect blood sugar levels over time .

    HYP: the researchers also controlled the A1s hemoglobin levels in the blood , which reflect the blood sugar levels in the dynamics .


  1894. REF: hemoglobin A1c is best kept below 7 percent , the researchers write .

    HYP: hemoglobin A1c test is better to keep below 7 percent , `` the researchers write .


  1895. REF: after surgery , the average hemoglobin A1c level fell from about 9 percent to about 6 percent .

    HYP: after surgery , the average level of hemoglobin A1C test decreased from roughly 9 % to approximately 6 % .


  1896. REF: in the medical therapy group , however , it remained steady at about 8 percent .

    HYP: in the therapeutic group , however , it has remained stable , at around 8 % .


  1897. REF: but this better `` glycemic control '' - as reflected by the improved hemoglobin A1c levels - did not reduce the mortality rate at five years , according to lead researcher Dr. Chih-cheng Hsu and colleagues .

    HYP: but the best indicators of glycemic control , reflecting good levels of hemoglobin A1C test , not reduced the mortality rate in five years , according to the study by Dr. Su Chi Cheng and colleagues .


  1898. REF: the research team also compared average outcomes with the two types of surgery .

    HYP: the research team also compare the average results of two types of surgical treatment .


  1899. REF: at the fifth year , compared to the sleeve gastrectomy group , the bypass surgery group had lost more weight ( 18.7 vs 14.2 kg ) , achieved larger drops in BMI ( 7.4 vs 5.1 ) and in hemoglobin A1c ( 3.1 percent vs 2.1 percent ) and were more likely to have complete diabetes remission ( 46.9 percent vs 16.7 percent ) .

    HYP: for the fifth year , compared with the group , Polc sleeve gastrectomy , shunt group lost more weight ( 18.7 kg versus 14.2 kg ) , achieved a greater reduction in BMI ( 7.4 vs. 5.1 ) and hemoglobin A1s ( 3.1 % versus 2.1 % ) , and was closer to a complete remission of diabetes ( 46.9 % versus 16.7 % ) .


  1900. REF: while the new study does not show a survival benefit or surgery after five years , there is evidence from a study of heavier people in Sweden that surgery does lead to a longer life , says Blackstone , of the University of Arizona College of Medicine-Phoenix .

    HYP: although the new study does not demonstrate the advantages of surgical methods in terms of life expectancy after five years , there is confirmation of the results of the study of people with excess body weight in Sweden that surgical treatment actually leads to increased life expectancy , according to Blackstone from the University College of Medicine in Phoenix , Arizona .


  1901. REF: in the Swedish study , obese people who had bariatric surgery were about 29 percent less likely to die over 15 years , compared to a group who tried more conventional methods .

    HYP: according to the Swedish research for people with obesity , bariatric intervention , the likelihood of dying for 15 years was approximately 29 % lower compared with the group , which uses a more traditional methods .


  1902. REF: though the new study did n't show a benefit in survival among surgery patients , Blackstone said it 's reassuring for people with a BMI under 35 interested in the procedure .

    HYP: although the new study did not show an increase in life expectancy , Blackstone said it is encouraging people with a BMI below 35 , interested in such a procedure .


  1903. REF: `` This is where this paper is critical , because it says this surgery is safe in that lower BMI group , '' with no increased risk of death or renal disease , she said .

    HYP: `` This report is very important because it argued that such surgery is safe in the group with a low BMI , where there is no increased risk of death or kidney disease , '' she said .


  1904. REF: Blackstone added that people and their doctors should start taking weight seriously once the patient 's BMI falls between 27 and 30 .

    HYP: Blackstone added that people and their doctors should begin to seriously treat weight as soon as the patient 's BMI range between 27 and 30 .


  1905. REF: `` I think we wait too long to get people to be serious about this , '' she said .

    HYP: `` I think we have to wait too long to get people to take this seriously , '' she said .


  1906. REF: I think that once they 've accumulated these genetic changes that hardwired their bodies into obesity and diabetes , reversing that is really hard .

    HYP: it seems to me that once they accumulate genetic changes that run in their bodies , obesity and diabetes , it is very difficult to turn back .

    HYP: `` I think the growth will be up to 50 percent , '' said the president of the Russian Hotel Association Gennady Lamshin .

    HYP: the new global market specific processes occur .


  2800. REF: in order to demonstrate them , Maksin distinguishes four skill levels for specialists : a and B for wealthy countries , and C and D for poor ones .

    HYP: to demonstrate , Maskin allocates four levels of specialists - And B for the rich countries , and D - for the poor .


  2801. REF: after globalisation , the D specialists from poor countries do n't have the required skill level to cooperate with specialists A and B from wealthy countries .

    HYP: after globalization specialists D from poor countries lack the level of qualifications to cooperate with specialists and B from rich countries .

    HYP: and if the salary level with workers from poor countries is growing thanks to cooperation with the employees of B D growth from rich , workers do not feel either their wages are falling .

    HYP: Kremer and E. Maskin offered a beautiful model , the alternative Ricardian theory of comparative advantage .

  2941. REF: environmentalists immediately accused the Prime Minister of populism : the outfit was purchased for 700 thousand dollars , while the clean up of the river requires at least eight billion .

  2984. REF: Xi urges to open economy wider to world

    HYP: Xi Jinping calls to make the economy more open to the world


  2985. REF: the economy must open wider to the outside world to fuel growth , President Xi Jinping told a group tasked with steering reform on Tuesday .

    HYP: the economy needs to become more open to the whole world to spur its growth , as President Xi Jinping said on Tuesday in a speech to the group facing the task of leadership reforms .


  2986. REF: `` China should be committed to attracting foreign investment and expertise , and improve opening-up policies , '' he said , addressing the 16th Meeting of the Central Leading Group for Deepening Overall Reform .

    HYP: `` China should focus on attracting foreign investors and experts and to develop a policy of openness , '' he said , referring to the participants of the 16th meeting of the Committee of the central leading group for comprehensively deepening reforms .


  2987. REF: promoting opening up while pushing forward reforms will add new impetus and vitality , and provide new room for economic growth , Xi said .

    HYP: according to him , the expansion of openness and deepening reforms will give the economy a boost and vitality and will provide a new space for economic development .


  2988. REF: the leading group adopted a series of guidelines including a negative list regulating market access , relaxation of border-control policies , encouraging state-owned enterprises ( SOE ) to absorb private capital and overhauling the resident registration system .

    HYP: the leading group adopted a number of directives , including the introduction of regulation investor access to the market , changing the rules of border controls , the promotion of state-owned enterprises ( SOE ) , attracting private capital and a review of the registration system .


  2989. REF: according to the statement , a negative list , identifying sectors and businesses that are off-limits for investment , will be drawn up .

    HYP: according to the statement , will be compiled a list of sectors of the economy and production , inaccessible for investment .


  2990. REF: the system will be gradually tested and improved through trial programs .

    HYP: the system will be gradually debugged through trial programs .


  2991. REF: the move is significant as it will give the market a bigger role in allocating resources , ensuring a law-based business environment and making the market more open , the statement said .

    HYP: this is an important step because it will give the market a bigger role in allocating resources , ensuring the legitimacy of the business sector and increasing openness , as said in the statement .


  2992. REF: the government will also loosen controls on the powers it delegates to companies , making sure that companies decide how to run their businesses .

    HYP: the government will also weaken the control of the powers granted to them to companies , ensuring that the companies themselves will conduct their business .


  2993. REF: the statement also said China will allow border areas to explore new models of cross-border economic cooperation and new mechanisms for promoting regional growth .

    HYP: the statement also says that China will allow border regions to develop new models of cross-border economic cooperation and new mechanisms to strengthen local growth .


  2994. REF: in a bid to open up state-controlled sectors , more areas will be open to private investment .

    HYP: even more areas will be available for private investors in order to increase the openness of state-controlled sectors of the economy .


  2995. REF: `` The government will not change its policy toward foreign investment , and will protect the lawful interests of foreign-funded companies and provide better services for them , '' said the statement .

    HYP: `` The government will not change its policy toward foreign investors and will defend the legitimate interests of companies with foreign funding , as well as provide them with the best conditions , '' it said in a statement .


  2996. REF: in addition , it will be made easier for foreigners to apply for permanent residence permits , or `` green card , '' by optimizing requirements and streamlining the application process .

    HYP: additionally will facilitate the procedure for submitting applications for permanent residence permits for foreigners , or `` green card '' by optimizing the requirements and simplifying the process of filing .


  2997. REF: guaranteeing lawyers ' right to practice and nurturing professional judges and prosecutors were also discussed at a meeting .

    HYP: the meeting also discussed ensuring the rights of lawyers and questions of professional training of judges and prosecutors .


  2998. REF: the meeting was also attended by Premier Li Keqiang , and senior leaders Liu Yunshan and Zhang Gaoli , according to a statement released after the meeting .

    HYP: according to an official report issued after the meeting , it was also attended by Prime Minister Li Keqiang and Liu Yunshan and Zhang Gaoli ministers .
